I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the People’s Republic of China (PRC) country programming midterm review 
mission, which took place in Beijing on 8–9 June 2010, the Government of the PRC requested 
that the Asian Development Bank (ADB) provide a capacity development technical assistance 
(TA) for Developing Smart Grid Technology for Efficient Utilization of Renewable Energy in the 
PRC. The TA was included in ADB's 2010 nonlending pipeline for the PRC.1 The concept paper 
was approved on 10 November 2010 and a memorandum of understanding was reached with 
the Ministry of Finance and the State Grid Corporation of China (SGCC) during the fact-finding 
mission. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Like many other countries, the PRC has recognized that it is facing imminent and severe 
challenges on energy security and climate change. The government has made great efforts to 
improve  energy  efficiency  and  reduce  carbon  dioxide  (CO )  emissions.  For  example,  its 
2
Eleventh Five Year Plan (2006–2010) mandates a 20% reduction in energy intensity by 2010.2 
In 2006, the government announced plans to develop a low-carbon economy in the National 
Evaluation Report on Climate Change. In 2007, the government declared that it would promote 
a  low-carbon  economy  by  improving  energy  efficiency,  developing  low-carbon  energy 
technology, expanding carbon sinks,3 and developing renewable energy.4 In November 2009 
the government announced its intention to reduce the carbon intensity5 of its gross domestic 
product (GDP) by 40%–45% by 2020 compared with the 2005 level.6 Being a high-priority area 
of the government, the energy sector is targeting a provision of 15% of total primary energy 
consumption using renewable resources by 2020.  
 
3.  The PRC is heavily dependent on coal for electricity production; it accounted for about 
80% of the total electricity produced in 20097 and about 50% of total CO  emissions in the 
2
country.  Due  to  the  fact  that  there  are  a  number  of  renewable  technologies  available  for 
electricity generation, the electricity sector is a key policy target area for addressing climate 
change and delivering near- and long-term CO  emission reductions. A low-carbon development 
2
path  requires  a  significant  portion  of  electricity  to  be  generated  from  renewable  energy 
resources. It is estimated that the PRC has about 1,000 gigawatts (GW) of exploitable wind 
resources.8 The rapid development of wind power has seen the capacity increase from 76 
megawatts (MW) in 2004 to about 17.6 GW in 2009 (footnote 7). This growth is expected to 
continue and the installed capacity is forecast to increase to 100.0 GW by 2020.  
 
4.  However, this momentum for wind energy may be impeded unless some challenges 
pertaining to grid integration of the dispersed renewable energy sources are addressed urgently. 
First, there is increased demand for adequate spinning reserve capacity to maintain the grid 
stability, as the existing electricity system is passively demand-driven. That is, when a consumer 
increases  their  electricity  use,  generation  somewhere  in  the  system  has  to  increase  by  a

2   
commensurate amount to satisfy that demand. Due to the intermittency of wind, however, wind 
power cannot respond directly to changes in consumer demand. So, when a certain amount of 
wind power capacity is connected it has to be backed up by the addition of a similar amount of 
spinning reserve capacity using traditional technologies in order to maintain grid stability. This 
creates additional costs for using wind power. At present, there is no generally accepted ceiling 
of wind power penetration.9 The limit for a particular grid will depend on many factors, such as 
existing  dispatchable  power  plants,  capacity  for  storage,  and  demand-side  management 
arrangements, etc. Given different research methodologies and different grid conditions, current 
studies on the connectivity of wind differ substantially and are hard to compare. In general, a 
penetration rate of 10% or lower is considered to be relatively manageable; with a penetration 
rate of 15% or higher, the additional costs increase exponentially.10 Therefore, without a firm 
understanding of the effects of large-scale (i.e., more than 15%) wind penetration on system 
stability, grid companies will continue to be hesitant partners in integrating more wind power in 
the grid. Some estimates showed that in 2009 about one-third of newly installed wind capacity in 
the PRC could not be integrated into the grid in a timely manner due to perceived impacts on 
grid stability. This has posed a risk as it not only precludes the development of renewable 
energy but also locks the PRC into a coal-dependent energy mix for the future at an early stage.  
 
5.  The  second  challenge  is  that  strategic  harmonization  between  renewable  energy 
development  and  grid  expansion  is  essential.  While  wind  farm  developers  are  greatly 
encouraged by strong incentives of higher tariff, the grid companies have been squeezed by the 
rising uploading tariff (both coal-fired and renewables) and the relatively stable selling price, and 
are  facing  difficulties  mobilizing  sufficient  funds  to  upgrade  transmission  and  distribution 
networks (e.g., rural subgrids) and accommodate more renewables (e.g., wind and solar). To 
promote  the  development  of  renewable  energy,  regulatory  and  policy  uncertainty  for  grid 
companies, who are responsible for network upgrading and development, has to be minimized. 
Standard procedures and codes to simplify the connectivity of renewable power plants with the 
grid have to be streamlined and sound tariffs for renewables and incentive mechanisms for the 
grid must be established.  
 
6.  The third challenge is that the economics of long-distance transmission lines have to be 
worked out. Wind power is not evenly distributed geographically and seasonally, and availability 
of peak wind may not coincide with peak demand for electricity. Areas with rich wind resources 
are mainly located in north and northwest PRC, several thousand kilometers from load centers 
in the eastern part of the PRC. A vast amount of wind power has to be transmitted long 
distances through ultra-high-voltage transmission lines. Also, northern PRC usually sees strong 
wind and peak demand for heat in winter. Prioritizing heat supply in winter means that wind 
power has to give way to coal-fired combined heat and power units. In some cases this leads to 
the idling of wind turbines. There is an urgent need to have much greater integration and to 
balance power supply and demand across a much wider area.   
 
7.  The  existing  grid  infrastructure  in  the  PRC,  along  with  the  regulatory  and  policy 
framework, was developed for the fossil-fuel-based economy, and in the future the grid will need 
to accommodate a far more diverse energy mix with a much higher proportion of renewable 
energy. This target will not be achieved without large-scale utilization of wind power. As the 
level of wind power generation increases, its intermittency will make it increasingly difficult for 
the grid operator to balance supply and demand. Potential solutions include, first, wind power 
                                                 
9  Wind penetration refers to the fraction of wind power capacity connected compared with the total available 
generation capacity in the grid. 
10 International Energy Agency. 2010. Wind Energy Annual Report 2009. Paris.

3
forecasting, i.e., making the intermittent wind more predictable. The purpose of forecasting is 
straightforward—if the grid operator has more accurate information on the day-ahead wind 
power generating capacity, then less extra spinning reserves are required. This will greatly 
reduce the total system operation costs, and grid operators will then be willing to integrate more 
wind farms in the system. A second solution is making demand flexible through the use of smart 
metering. Currently most customers are not exposed to real-time pricing and do not generally 
have  the  technical  means  to  respond  rapidly  to  price  changes.  Variations  in  demand  are 
therefore met by ramping up or down the generators. This passive operation model can be 
changed  if  smart  metering  enables  nonessential  appliances  to  be  switched  on  and  off 
automatically  in  response  to  real-time  price  fluctuations.  There  is  an  urgent  need  to 
comprehensively analyze these issues and help the PRC create a more enabling environment 
for renewable energy development.  
 
8.  A smart grid is a power grid that can intelligently manage demand and supply across the 
whole electricity value chain—generation, transmission, distribution, and consumption—through 
robust two-way communications. Smart grid deployment is widely believed to be a key for 
employing renewable energy at large scale to reduce carbon intensity and address climate 
change. The SGCC is responsible for managing more than 80% of the transmission system in 
the PRC. It announced its smart grid development plan in mid-2009, aiming to establish by 2020 
a “strong and smart grid” to improve the grid security, intelligent level of distribution, and 
integration of renewable energy. The TA will directly address key challenges faced by SGCC 
smart grid development plan. 
 
9.  Climate change is not only an environmental problem but also a critical development 
issue. Its adverse impacts will disproportionally affect the poor, as they are more reliant on their 
direct natural environment. In its long-term strategic framework 2008–2020 (Strategy 2020),11 
ADB  has  identified  energy  as  a  core  operational  sector  and  achieving  environmental 
sustainability  as  a  strategic  priority  in  pursuing  its  mission  to  help  its  developing  member 
countries  reduce  poverty  and  improve  living  conditions  and  quality  of  life.  ADB’s  country 
partnership strategy for energy operation in the PRC12 also emphasized clean and efficient 
technologies to promote the utilization of renewable energy and help reduce greenhouse gas 
emissions. There is a strong and clear consistency between the strategic priorities of ADB and 
the PRC in the energy sector.  
 
10.  The TA is the first TA of ADB to promote smart grid technology in the PRC, and is a very 
good fit with the SGCC’s smart grid development plan. By comprehensively analyzing issues 
surrounding poor grid integration of wind and other intermittent renewable energy sources, the 
TA  will  provide  key  enabling  conditions  for  larger  renewable  energy  utilization  and  can 
accelerate and intensify renewable energy development in the PRC. It is estimated that a 
successful deployment of smart grid technology will help the PRC reduce its CO  emissions by 
2
1.02 billion tons by 2020 compared to the 2005 level.13

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.   The impact of the TA will be increased utilization of renewable energy and reduced CO  
2
emissions in the PRC. The outcome of the TA will be improved capacity for grid integration of 
wind power plants in the SGCC. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The proposed TA is designed to help the SGCC develop smart grid technology for 
efficient utilization of renewable energy. The outputs of the TA are as follows: (i) a smart grid 
road map for harmonizing renewable energy development with the grid expansion in a regional 
grid is developed; (ii) technical standards for the connectivity of renewable energy to the grid are 
codified and upgraded; (iii) short-term day-ahead wind power forecasting systems are upgraded 
and piloted in a selected power dispatch center; and (iv) training activities are provided and 
lessons learned disseminated to other places and stakeholders, and a policy note on smart grid 
development is prepared for high-level governmental officials. 
 
13.  Close coordination will be maintained with stakeholders during implementation to ensure 
that the TA takes into account existing studies, government priorities, plans, and results of pilot 
tests. Experts from research institutes and universities will be consulted so as to increase 
understanding of current practices and identify pragmatic methods for developing smart grid 
technology. Consultants will be required to examine international best practices which can be 
used in delivering the TA outputs. The consultants are required to maintain close working 
relations with ADB and the executing agency and implementing agency. Tripartite meetings 
among ADB, the executing agency and implementing agency, and the consultants will be held 
periodically to provide guidance to the consultants and to review their reports. Workshops and 
seminars will be held to collect comments on consultants’ reports and also to disseminate the 
main findings of the TA.  
 
14.  The  TA  includes  innovative  ideas  and  approaches,  but  the  associated  risks  are 
considered manageable as the TA will be implemented in close cooperation with professional 
technical experts nominated by the executing agency and its focus is on a narrow policy area. 
The major assumptions are that the smart grid road map and technical standards recommended 
by  ADB  consultants  are  accepted  and  implemented  by  the  grid  company.  Since  the  TA 
addresses an ongoing core issue of large unconnected wind power capacity and fits well with 
the SGCC’s target of setting up a smart grid by 2020, the SGCC has good ownership of the TA. 
To ensure that the designed outputs can be delivered on time, the project team extensively 
discussed the TA outline and key outputs with experts, and support from the top management of 
the SGCC was sought on the TA design.    
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $1,200,000 equivalent. It is proposed that 
ADB provide $900,000 equivalent on a grant basis from the Multi-Donor Clean Energy Fund14 
under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility administered by ADB. The government 
will finance the remaining $300,000 equivalent through in-kind contributions including office 
                                                 
14 Contributors: the governments of Australia, Norway, Spain, and Sweden.

5
accommodation, logistic facilities, and remuneration of counterpart staff. The TA cost estimates 
and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The North China Grid Company has been designated as the executing agency, and 
project management officers have been nominated by SGCC to guide the TA implementation on 
a  day-to-day  basis.  The  TA  will  be  carried  out  by  a  team  of  consultants  with  extensive 
knowledge and expertise in (i) smart grid development and planning, (ii) grid operation and 
power dispatch, (iii) electrical and electronic engineering, (iv) meteorology, (v) wind power 
engineering, (vi) wind power forecasting, (vii) energy economics and policy analyses, (viii) 
environmental  and  social  safeguards,  and  (ix)  institutional  capacity  building  and  public 
information sharing. The consulting work will comprise about 11 person-months of international 
consultants and 50 person-months of national consultants. Similar expertise is required for both 
international and national consultants in the same area. The outline terms of reference for 
consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
17.  ADB,  in  consultation  with  the  executing  agency  will  select  and  engage  consultants 
through a consulting firm in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, 
as amended from time to time) using the quality- (80%) and cost-based (20%) selection method. 
The consulting firm will be required to submit a simplified technical proposal covering all aspects 
of the terms of reference. For output 2, a suitable software package will be purchased if possible, 
and upgraded as necessary to satisfy the needs of wind power forecasting. The wind power 
forecasting specialists and meteorologists are responsible for preparing specifications of the 
wind power forecasting software, and procure and evaluate the performance of the program. All 
software  and  equipment  procurement  will  be  carried  out  using  the  shopping  method  in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). All 
equipment  purchased under  the TA  will  be turned  over  to  the  executing  agency  after  TA 
completion. 
 
18.  Training, seminars, conferences and workshops, and study tours will be administered 
through a consulting services contract. Consultants are expected to provide training materials, 
and  important  topics  will  be  highlighted  during  workshops  and  seminars.  Workshops  and 
seminars will be held to collect comments on consultants' reports and also to disseminate the 
main findings of the TA. Consultants are required to summarize seminars, workshops, and 
training results and report to the executing agency and ADB. To facilitate TA implementation, an 
advance payment facility is requested, and TA funds will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
19.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months from April 2011 to September 2012. The 
consultants are required to submit TA deliverables and progress reports in a timely manner. 
Detailed requirements for deliverables and reports are included in the outline terms of reference 
for consultants.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $900,000 to the People’s 
Republic of China to be financed on a grant basis by the Multi-Donor Clean Energy Fund under 
the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility for Developing Smart Grid Technology for 
Efficient Utilization of Renewable Energy, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be implemented in consultation with the executing 
agency  and  the  implementing  agency  and  stakeholders,  including  the  National  Energy 
Administration and State Electricity Regulatory Commission. The TA has the following outputs:  
(i)  Output 1: A smart grid road map harmonizing renewable energy development 
with grid expansion in a regional grid.  
(ii)  Output 2: Technical standards for the connectivity of renewable energy to the 
grid. 
(iii)  Output 3: A short-term day-ahead wind power forecasting system and pilot in a 
selected power dispatch center. 
(iv)  Output 4: Training and information dissemination. 
 
2.  The international consultants (11 person-months) will coordinate their work with the 
national consultants (50 person-months). Consultants required include experts specializing in (i) 
smart grid development and planning, (ii) grid operation and power dispatch, (iii) electrical and 
electronic engineering, (iv) meteorology, (v) wind power engineering, (vi) wind power forecasting, 
(vii) energy economics and electricity market reform, and (viii) institutional capacity building and 
public  information  sharing.  Similar  expertise  is  required  for  both  international  and  national 
consultants in the same area.  
 
A.  Consultants 
 
1.  Smart Grid Development and Planning Specialists (1 international, 6 person-
months; 1 national, 6 person-months) 
3.  The international consultant will be responsible for pulling together outputs from other 
consultants  in  a  coherent  report  covering  all  aspects  of  the  TA.  The  consultants  will  (i) 
understand  the  national  power  sector  policies  and  development  strategy;  (ii)  have  broad 
experience in ultra-high-voltage power grid development planning; (iii) understand the traditional 
approach to power grid planning in the People’s Republic of China (PRC), including technical 
standards, regulatory mechanism, and approval procedures, etc.; (iv) be familiar with the latest 
developments  in  smart  grid  technology  and  be  able  to  recommend  internationally  proven 
technologies, and describe the rationale for technical considerations, investment requirements, 
and implementation schedules based on the PRC’s development status; and (v) thoroughly 
understand technologies for, and methods of, connecting renewables to the power grid. The 
consultants will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  Act as team leader to coordinate preparation and delivery of outputs, as directed 
by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the executing agency. 
(ii)  Review the best practice of international experiences on smart grid development 
and the connectivity of renewables. 
(iii)  Identify technical and institutional barriers to effectively connecting renewable 
energy to the power grid.   
(iv)  Assess the feasibility of conducting intelligent demand-side management through 
smart metering in pilot places.  
(v)  Analyze  and  develop a  smart  grid road  map  harmonizing  renewable  energy 
development with grid expansion in a regional grid.  
(vi)  Prepare  a  policy  note  on  the  development  of  a  smart  grid  for  high-level 
governmental officials based on the TA findings.    
(vii)  Identify  training  requirements,  develop  a  training  manual,  and  provide  the 
necessary training if necessary.

Appendix 3  11 
 
2.  Grid Operation and Power Dispatch Specialists (2 national, 11 person-months 
in total)    
4.  The consultants will understand (i) the traditional approach to grid operation and power 
dispatch in the PRC, including working procedures, emergency plans, and regulatory standards, 
etc.; and (ii) the roles and responsibilities of entities related to grid operation and power dispatch. 
The consultants will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  Investigate the demand and supply situations in the pilot province based on 
historical data on coal-fired generation units, renewable plants, and imported 
power. 
(ii)  Review national or industrial codes and standards for grid operation and power 
dispatch,  and  supply  security  requirements,  emergency  plans,  regulatory 
mechanisms, and geological distribution of power plants in the selected pilot 
province, etc.  
(iii)  Assess  the  effectiveness  of  different  grid  operation  and  power  dispatch 
technologies  based  on  historical  data  of  the  selected  pilot  province  and 
international best practices; clarify merits and problems. 
(iv)  Assess  the  potential  influence  of  intelligent  demand-side  management  (e.g., 
smart metering) on the grid operation and power dispatch, and specify related 
technical requirements.   
(v)  Make suggestions on how to harmonize renewable energy development with grid 
expansion in the selected province based on its development status.  
 
3.  Electrical and Electronic Engineer (1 national, 5 person-months)   
5.  The consultant will understand (i) power sector technical standards, emergency plans, 
and regulatory procedures for security of supply in the PRC, etc.; and (ii) technologies and 
methods of connecting renewables to the power grids at different voltage levels in consideration 
of supply security. The consultant will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  Identify technical and institutional barriers to connecting renewables to the power 
grid.   
(ii)  Develop new technical standards for the connectivity of renewable energy to the 
grid as required, based on international best practices.  
 
4.  Wind Power Engineer (1 national, 2 person-months)  
6.  The consultant will understand (i) power sector technical standards, emergency plans, 
and regulatory procedures, for security of supply in the PRC, etc.; and (ii) latest technology 
development in wind power, particularly on wind turbine dynamic electromechanical modeling. 
The consultant will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  Identify technical and institutional barriers to connecting wind to the power grids 
at different voltage levels. 
(ii)  Identify  technical  and  institutional  barriers  to  long-distance  wind  power 
transmission.   
(iii)  Develop new technical standards for the connectivity of wind power to the grid as 
required, based on international best practices.  
 
5.  Meteorologists (1 international, 1 person-month; 1 national, 5 person-months) 
7.  The consultants will undertake the following tasks:

12  Appendix 3 
(i)  Review historical records on wind speed, direction, distribution, periods of time, 
etc. for selected wind farms.  
(ii)  Assess  the  distribution  of  measurement  towers  in  terms  of  topographical 
environment of the selected wind farms, and make suggestions on wind data 
collection.   
(iii)  Use measure–correlate–predict analysis to assess the wind resources at the 
selected wind farm sites.  
(iv)  Provide complete guidance for wind farm developers to build a three-dimensional 
grid to measure atmospheric disturbance at the project site.  
(v)  Use  the  numerical  weather  prediction  approach  to  simulate  the  atmospheric 
behavior at the project site. 
(vi)  Coordinate  with  the  wind  power  capacity  forecasting  specialists  to  develop 
software systems for short- and medium-term wind capacity prediction.  
 
6.  Wind  Power  Forecasting  Specialists  (1  international,  4  person-months;  2 
national, 10 person-months in total) 
8.  The consultants will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  Review  international  best  practices  on  wind  power  capacity  forecasting, 
particularly for short periods.   
(ii)  Based on the capabilities of specific wind turbines and historical data on wind 
resources  at  the  pilot  project  site,  build  up  a  power  curve  to  simulate  the 
generation capacity of specific wind turbines at different wind speeds.  
(iii)  Use data collected through the numerical weather prediction approach to adjust 
the power curve.  
(iv)  Coordinate  with  meteorologists  and  develop  software  systems  for  short-term 
wind capacity prediction.  
 
7.  Energy Economist (1 national, 5 person-months) 
9.  The consultant will understand (i) national policies on power sector development, and 
existing institutional and regulatory mechanisms in the PRC for power grid development; and (ii) 
the strategies of the executing and implementing agencies on smart grid development. The 
consultant will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  Review international practices on smart grid development and connectivity of 
renewables. 
(ii)  Investigate the demand and supply situations in the pilot province based on 
historical data on coal-fired generation units, renewable plants, and imported 
power. 
(iii)  Identify economic and institutional barriers to effectively connecting renewable 
energy to power grids; estimate related costs (e.g., spinning reserves due to 
intermittency of renewables) and benefits (e.g., carbon dioxide reduction) for 
connecting renewable energy in the pilot province.  
(iv)  Assess  the  economic  feasibility  of  conducting  intelligent  demand-side 
management (e.g., smart metering), and estimate related investment costs. 
(v)  Coordinate  with  other  experts,  describe  investment  requirements  and 
implementation schedules under different technical scenarios, based on the pilot 
province situation.  
(vi)  Help the team leader prepare a smart grid road map harmonizing renewable 
energy development with grid expansion for the pilot province.

Appendix 3  13 
8.  Environment and Social Safeguard Specialist (1 national, 3 person-months) 
10.  The consultant’s tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Review  related  national  environmental  standards  for  power  generation, 
transmission, and distribution, particularly on grid development.  
(ii)  Conduct  an  environmental  impact  assessment  for  the  proposed  smart  grid 
development road map in the pilot province. 
(iii)  Prepare analysis for the report on environmental safeguard issues.  
(iv)  Ensure the TA deliverables and progress reports are consistent with national 
policy and standards. 
 
9.  Institutional Capacity Building Specialist (1 national, 3 person-months)  
11.  The consultant will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  In  consultation  with  other  experts,  schedule  training  programs,  seminars, 
workshops, and study tours. 
(ii)  Organize international and national workshops and seminars to progressively 
discuss and disseminate TA findings. 
(iii)  Work with other experts to develop training materials, workshop and seminar 
proceedings, and presentation handouts, etc.  
(iv)  Work with other experts to identify international and national participants and 
prepare  invitation  letters,  as  directed  by  the  executing  and  implementing 
agencies. 
(v)  Summarize seminar and workshop results and provide summary reports to ADB 
and the executing agency.  
 
B.  Reporting Requirements 
 
12.  All TA reports will be written in English and translated into Chinese. The consultants will 
prepare the following reports: 
(i)  An inception report within 1 month after the start of the TA. The report will 
summarize the initial findings and suggest changes, if any, to the TA design, 
methodology, and time schedule. 
(ii)  A midterm report to the executing agency and ADB. The midterm report will focus 
on (a) presenting to policy makers and stakeholders concerned TA findings and 
recommendations, (b) facilitating idea exchange and gathering comments, and (c) 
allowing ADB and policy makers to digest and discuss feedback received. 
(iii)  A draft final report to the executing agency and ADB. The draft final report will 
cover  all  aspects  of  the  TA  and  focus  on  presenting  to  policy  makers  and 
concerned stakeholders the TA findings and gathering more comments.  
(iv)  A final report to the executing agency and ADB. The final report will be prepared 
taking into account (a) comments of the executing agency and ADB on the draft 
final report, and (b) discussions during the final TA workshop.
